SUMMARY: MlrA is a regulator of curli production in an avian pathogenic Escherichia coli strain and in Salmonella enterica serovar Typhimurium [11489123]. Shiga toxin-encoding prophages have been observed to integrate at mlrA gene of enterohemorrhagic E. coli [11111050]. MlrA is a member of MerR family, containing conserved N-terminal DNA-binding domain present in members of this family [11489123, 20874755]. On or hand, its C-terminal domain, probably used by a yet-to-be-identified effector, showed no similarity to any of hirto-characterized MerR family members [20874755]. MlrA binds an AAAGTTGTACA(12N)TGCACAATTTT palindromic sequence and probably induces DNA underwinding, as in case of MerR [20874755]. Based on site identified on csgDp1 promoter, sites for anor four genes were identified, two of which are transcriptional regulators [20874755]. MlrA is found at a higher level in hierarchy of transcription factor network [20874755, 20491932]. Expression of mlrA gene is RpoS-regulated in an avian pathogenic E. coli strain [11489123]. MlrA is part of a signaling cascade that controls curli biosynsis, in which c-di-GMP regulates through diguanylate cyclase/phosphodiesterase (DGC/PDE) pair YegH/YhjH (module I) and activity of YdaM/YciR pair (module II), which forms a signaling complex with MlrA. Gmr functions as a connector and a trigger enzyme in local c-di-GMP signaling; its direct inhibition of YdaM is relieved when it binds and degrades c-di-GMP, allowing YdaM to activate transcription factor MlrA [23708798]. MlrA: MerR-like regulator A [11489123].
